course_title: Topics in History and Text: Health & Healing: Greek World
class_notes:
(Same as ANCMED 202R 1 and HLTH 285 1)
The course focuses on the ancient Greek experience of health and healing from Homer through the Hellenistic era (roughly the 8th through 1st centuries BCE).  We will also look at the Roman era continuation of Greek medical traditions through the work and career of Galen of Pergamum. A major theme of the seminar will be understanding the contemporaneous emergence and continued success of Hippocratic medicine and Asclepian religion/cult, two distinct but related ways of thinking about health and healing. Emphasis will be on primary sources, both texts such as the Hippocratic writings and the testimonia of Asclepius' healing, as well as archaeological and material evidence from the sanctuaries of Asclepius located throughout the Greek world.
course_description: The course demonstrates how literary, artistic, and/or cinematic texts, when understood in relation to the context of their production, can be used to study selected historical themes.
